Identification of unusual patterns, errors, or unexpected behaviour in data that may indicate operational issues, fraud, or data quality problems.

Often used in monitoring systems and quality control processes.

Typical examples include sales summaries, usage reports, and performance dashboards.

Commonly used to explain performance changes, failures, or unexpected trends.

cards.title: Google Cloud
cards.description: Google Cloud

cards.title: Google Cloud  Data Analytics (The Brain)
cards.description: Definition: Large-scale data processing and real-time business intelligence. Key Services: BigQuery (Warehouse), Dataflow (Streaming), Pub/Sub (Messaging), Looker (BI). BigQuery is now a "Data Intelligence" engine that runs ML models directly on your data in real-time.

cards.title: Google Cloud  Developer Tools & Firebase (The Workbench)
cards.description: Definition: Tools to build, deploy, and scale web and mobile applications. Key Services: Cloud Build (CI/CD), Artifact Registry, Firebase (App Dev Platform).  Firebase Data Connect allows developers to bridge mobile apps directly into PostgreSQL/AlloyDB.

cards.title: Google Cloud  Networking (The Nervous System)
cards.description: Definition: High-speed, private global network connecting apps and users. Key Services: VPC (Network), Cloud Load Balancing, Cloud CDN, Service Directory.  "Cross-Cloud Network" simplifies connecting GCP resources directly to AWS or Azure.

cards.title: Google Cloud AI & Machine Learning (The Intelligence)
cards.description: Definition: The platform for building Generative AI, agents, and custom models. Key Services: Vertex AI (The Platform), Gemini (Models), Vertex AI Agents. Major focus on "Agentic AI"�autonomous bots that perform multi-step business tasks.

cards.title: Google Cloud Application Integration (The Glue)
cards.description: Definition: Orchestrating workflows and connecting APIs across services. Key Services: Apigee (API Management), Workflows (Orchestration), Eventarc (Event-driven).  Eventarc now supports cross-platform events (e.g., an S3 upload in AWS triggering a GCP function).

cards.title: Google Cloud Compute (The Engine)
cards.description: Definition: Flexible infrastructure for VMs, containers, and serverless code. Key Services: Compute Engine (VMs), GKE (Kubernetes), Cloud Run (Serverless Containers). "Cloud Run Functions" has fully unified serverless execution into a single, simplified workflow.

cards.title: Google Cloud Databases (The Ledger)
cards.description: Definition: Scalable relational and NoSQL databases for global applications. Key Services: Cloud Spanner (Global Relational), AlloyDB (PostgreSQL-compatible), Firestore (NoSQL).  AlloyDB AI integration, allowing vector search and ML embedding directly in the database.

cards.title: Google Cloud Management & Operations (The Oversight)
cards.description: Definition: Monitoring, logging, and managing cloud health and costs. Key Services: Cloud Logging, Cloud Monitoring, Error Reporting, Cloud Deployment Manager.  Gemini in Operations allows you to troubleshoot system errors using natural language prompts.

cards.title: Google Cloud Security & Identity (The Guardrails)
cards.description: Definition: Zero-trust security, identity management, and threat detection. Key Services: IAM (Access), Security Command Center, Identity Platform, BeyondCorp (Zero Trust).  Chronicle Security Operations uses AI to automate incident response and threat hunting.

cards.title: Google Cloud Security Model
cards.description: Google Cloud’s security model focusing on infrastructure protection, identity control, and workload security.

cards.title: Google Cloud Storage (The Memory)
cards.description: Definition: High-performance storage for objects, blocks, and shared files. Key Services: Cloud Storage (Object), Persistent Disk (Block), Cloud Filestore. Automatic "AI-Stream" metadata tagging within Cloud Storage for instant Vertex AI indexing.

cards.description: Internal controls, policies, and frameworks for managing data, systems, and processes effectively.

cards.title: Monte Carlo Simulations
cards.description: A Monte Carlo simulation replaces fixed task durations with probability distributions to account for uncertainty, running thousands of project iterations to calculate every possible outcome. The result is a statistical "S-curve" that allows leaders to set deadlines based on specific confidence levels (e.g., P80) rather than optimistic guesses.
